data.text: Contents
Introduction

Specimens and samples are regularly taken via surgical, endoscopic, procedures. The Trust requires that every specimen reaches the Histology or Cytology departments without undue delay and in optimum condition. All staff dealing with patients on the peri-operative, endoscopic, inpatient and outpatient pathways must be aware of and follow the procedure for the correct handling of specimens and samples including correct documentation, safe handling and appropriate dispatch.
The laboratory examination of specimens is an important step in determining the subsequent treatment of patients.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To ensure that all staff involved are aware of the process to follow when handling urgent and non-urgent samples / specimens.
The  responsibility  for  accurately  labelling  specimen  pots  and  ensuring specimens are placed into correctly labelled specimen pots lies with the assisting nurse/theatre practitioner.

In endoscopy once specimens are taken and documentation complete, it is the responsibility of the designated nurse in charge of the area to ensure they are transported to the laboratory in a timely manner.
For any specimen from a suspected cancer or a target patient, the histology form must be marked with T stamp.
If there is any doubt about specimens the consultant in charge of the case must be contacted immediately for clarification
To ensure that specimens are correctly handled within the theatre department. To ensure that specimens are sent to the appropriate laboratories for analysing
To ensure that all staff involved are aware of what process to follow when handling urgent and non-urgent specimens.
To provide an Audit trail for ensuring best practice
Definitions

table_items.text: A person whose task is to co-ordinate the day to day activity in the theatres
A specialist doctor who gives expert advice in a hospital.
A hospital doctor junior to the consultant.
Theatre practitioner directly involved with the surgery within the sterile field
Theatre practitioner assisting the scrub practitioner outside the sterile field
Support staff for all members of staff in theatres, plus portering duties
An unforeseen or sudden unexpected occurrence demanding immediate action.

A specimen is a body substance, tissue or organ (e.g.: appendix or spleen), taken from a person for the purpose of analysis. The aim of such analysis is to identify disease and to provide direction for appropriate treatment.
Specimens which are taken from a patient with a known risk of blood borne virus.
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health
World Health Organisation (WHO) Safer Surgical Checklist
Specimens must be checked in accordance with the WHO checklist at sign out.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The Chief Executive, as accounting officer has overall responsibility to ensure that arrangements are secured for the safe and accurate process of specimen and sample collection. This responsibility has been delegated to the Director of Nursing and the Medical Director.

The Directors of Nursing and Medical Directors will be responsible for the implementation of this procedure ensuring that the Trust provides/supports the training required for staff to undertake and that there is appropriate competency framework to support this.
Clinical Governance Groups are responsible for promoting and disseminating good practice within their directorates and ensuring that Trust policies and procedures are adhered to.

Clinical Directors / General Managers are responsible for ensuring staff involved in all aspects of specimen and sample collection undergo relevant training for the procedures that they are required to undertake, prior to performing these tasks, in accordance with this document.

Unit / Ward / Department managers are responsible for identifying training needs and ensuring staff training is available for all staff and that all staff expected to undertake this procedure are trained against competency framework.

Clinicians are responsible for ensuring they give clear instructions to the assisting nurse, medical staff and other multidisciplinary staff, allowing them the time to follow this procedure. They are responsible for ensuring adequate specimens and samples are taken and ensuring accurate clinical information / specimen / sample details recorded on the forms.
Clinical and non-clinical staff are responsible for ensuring that they have been trained and are competent to assist in the collection of tissue specimens and

samples including accurate labelling and recording of specimens and must adhere to this procedure. They are responsible for ensuring specimens are transported to the appropriate laboratory in a timely manner
The policy for the labelling transfer and safe handling of specimens has been segregated to ensure that the appropriate specialities have the correct processes in place:
Endoscopy
Equipment
Endoscopy procedure room
Patient trolley
Endoscope suitable to procedure
Biopsy forceps
Labels identifying possible sites for biopsy
Biopsy pot containing formaldehyde 4% solution
Biopsy paper
Surgical gloves
Gauze
Histology request form
Clinical waste bag
Personal protective clothing
Large sharps disposal container
Pre-procedure Room Preparation

table_items.text: Assisting nurse to ensure procedure room is clean, tidy and any necessary equipment prepared for the next patient.
To conform to infection control protocols and ensure efficiency.
Ensure any previous patient's healthcare records and specimens are processed appropriately and removed from procedure room.
To minimise risk of mislabelled specimens.
Ensure appropriate specimen labels available for procedure to be undertaken e.g. colonoscopy, cystoscopy.
To ensure labels available for clearly identifying specimen site.

data.text: Pre-procedure Patient Preparation

table_items.text: Patient to be admitted using the appropriate forms and guidelines. Including; issuing the patient's identification band and checking details with patient and against the healthcare records e.g. full name, date of birth and hospital number
To confirm patient identity and fitness for procedure.
Explain procedure, and ensure informed consent obtained and the patient's comfort and privacy.
To maximise patient understanding and co-operation.
Ensure patient is appropriately prepared for the procedure (e.g. for colonoscopy ensure bowel is emptied and necessary clothing is removed).
To maximise success of procedure and patient comfort.
Upon the patient entering procedure room confirm patient identity and check correct notes including labels etc. are available.
To confirm patient identity and eliminate risk of clinical incident.

data.text: Acquiring tissue sample

table_items.text: Assisting nurse to wear appropriate personal protective equipment i.e. apron, gloves and goggles or visor.
To conform to BSG guidelines and infection control policy to prevent cross infection.
During the procedure the endoscopist will indicate to the assisting nurse if there is a need to take specimens.
To allow the assisting nurse to prepare specimen pot and forceps.

Assisting Nurse (or in the case of colonoscopy the Named Nurse) collects specimen pot from storage area: Room 1 – basket on shelf next to scope storage cupboards Room 2 – Drawer near to drugs cupboard Room 3 – Basket on monitor trolley (Un-used specimen pots are not to be stored on work area).
To minimise risk of re-using a previously used but unlabelled specimen pot.

Assisting Nurse (or in the case of Colonoscopy the named nurse) applies a label indicating site of area to be sampled to the specimen pot and a corresponding label to the nursing admission sheet. For specimen collection during cystoscopy these labels will need to applied once the procedure is completed.
To prevent re-use of unlabelled specimen pots. To ensure site of specimen is clearly labelled on pot and prevent mis- labelling of specimens. To maintain sterility during procedure.
During the procedure the assisting endoscopy nurse selects the appropriate biopsy forceps, retaining packaging and
To allow tracking label on forceps packaging to be retained. To enable the endoscopist to pass the
passes them, jaws first, to the endoscopist keeping hold of the handle.
Upon instruction from the endoscopist the assisting nurse opens the jaws of the biopsy forceps.
To ensure the forceps are positioned to take a tissue sample.
Upon instruction from the endoscopist the endoscopy nurse closes the jaws of the biopsy forceps.
The endoscopist makes a short tug on the forceps and instructs the endoscopy nurse to remove the forceps from the endoscope.
The endoscopy nurse uses gauze to wipe biopsy forceps cable on removal from the endoscope.
To aid removal of forceps, remove debris found on the cable and minimise risk of any body fluid spraying.

For gastrointestinal specimens the assisting endoscopy nurse ensures the tissue sample is orientated onto the biopsy paper. Then after removing lid and confirming specimen pot is new, place the samples into the prepared pot containing formaldehyde 4% solution. (For colonoscopy the assisting nurse also needs to confirm that the site detailed on the identifying label is correct at the time the specimen is placed in the pot as this would have been added by the named nurse prior to the procedure). For cystoscopy and bronchoscopy specimens the samples are dispensed directly into the prepared pot containing formaldehyde 4% solution after confirming it is a new pot. The pot must then be fully labelled with Surname First name DOB, hospital number and specimen site.

To preserve the tissue sample for analysis and obtain the best possible histological sample. To minimise risk of re-using a previously used pot. To allow assisting nurse to be sure specimen site labelled accurately. Samples are too small to place on biopsy paper.
For GI procedures indicate number of tissue samples taken from any particular site on specimen pot (Not possible for cystoscopy or bronchoscopy as samples are too small) and later on specimen form
This is for information only and not used a tracking system

Once all tissue samples are taken from any particular site the assisting nurse must ensure the pot is sealed and placed away from the work area. If further samples are required repeat from step 6.3.2.
To minimise risk of specimen pots being re-used in error.
The endoscopist will indicate to the assisting nurse if biopsy forceps are used to take a tissue sample from a suspected cancer in the upper GI tract as new forceps must be
To minimise the risk of mis-diagnosis.
used if further specimens are needed from a second site.

Dispose of single use biopsy forceps by wrapping them around a gloved hand and pull glove over forceps so they are contained inside. Place in large sharps bin. For re-usable cystoscopy forceps place in tray and take to decontamination room with cystoscope.
To ensure contaminated forceps remain neatly in sharps bin and to comply with Trust infection control policy. To allow for cleaning & packaging to take place prior to sending off to be autoclaved.

data.text: Post endoscopic procedure

table_items.text: Once the procedure is finished the assisting nurse completes details on specimen pots (in the case of colonoscopy this is likely to have been carried out by the named nurse but the assisting nurse needs to check for accuracy) and histology form, checking all details for accuracy against patient identification band and healthcare records. Assisting nurse to confirm specimen sites with named nurse against labels recorded on nursing admission sheet.

To ensure an accurate histology form completed with correct patient details and site of sample. Acts as a double check to ensure the correct biopsy sites and number of specimen pots are being processed.
Endoscopist to complete histopathology form prior to typing / writing endoscopy report.
To ensure specimens are dealt with promptly.
For any specimen from a suspected cancer or a target patient, the histology form must be marked with T stamp.
To ensure prompt analysis of specimen to optimise patient care pathway and ensure targets are met.
Named nurse to record on admission sheet the name of the assisting nurse along with a clear record of number of specimens taken. For in-patient record on endoscopy checklist

Named nurse to apply forceps tracking label to admission sheet.(For in-patients apply to endoscopy checklist) (Patient and named nurse to remain in The procedure room until all checks have taken place.)
To allow accurate tracking and record keeping.

Once specimen pots are labelled, histology form and all checks for accuracy have been completed the assisting nurse places the specimen pots in specimen bags. These are then placed in the central specimen box located on nurses station outside procedure room 1. All details of each specimen must
To ensure accurate tracking and record keeping system.
be recorded in the specimen record book. This entry must be clear, accurate, dated and signed.
Ensure patient is comfortable and taken to recovery.
To ensure patient health, safety, wellbeing, comfort and dignity.
Provide explanations to the patient and advice on obtaining results together with verbal advice on care and wellbeing after the procedure (to be supported with written information)
To ensure patient knowledge and awareness.
Assisting nurse to ensure procedure room is clean, tidy and ready for next patient.
To conform to infection control protocols, ensure efficiency and eliminate risk of clinical incident.

data.text: Delivering specimens to laboratory

table_items.text: Sister or senior staff nurse in charge must ensure all specimen pots and the completed specimen forms are taken to Histopathology within agreed timescales: Morning samples – To be delivered to laboratory at the end of the morning lists (usually by departmental assistant). Afternoon samples – To be delivered to the laboratory at the end of the afternoon list if complete before laboratory closing time (before 5.00pm). If not, to go early the following morning.
To prevent delay in diagnosis, comply with Trust protocols.
On delivering specimens to the laboratory ensure specimen record book is signed by the receiving laboratory staff.
To provide a tracking record. To be used for audit.

data.text: **Please note for cystoscopy and flexible sigmoidoscopy procedures where a second nurse  may  not  be  present  (i.e.  named  nurse  will  also  be  the  assisting  nurse)  the responsibilities of both the named nurse and the assisting nurse lie with that person.
Safe handling and dispatching of specimens (All MSE Theatres –
including CTC and Day Stay units)

The care and preservation of the specimen is the overall responsibility of the scrub practitioner during surgical procedures. They must check that all the information and documentation are correct before the specimen leaves the clinical area.

Specimen identification begins at the time the specimen is removed from the patient. The scrub practitioner must clarify with the surgeon the nature and site (where applicable, e.g. left or right) of the specimen.  In order to prevent the drying out of specimens, they should be handed off the sterile field as soon as they are taken and the surgeon has given consent for their removal.

Before handing the specimen off the sterile field, the scrub practitioner must check with the surgeon whether the specimen should be placed in a container containing a preservative medium, or whether it should be left dry.

Specimens must be handled carefully to avoid crushing or distortion of anatomical detail, using aseptic technique to avoid inadvertent contamination of the site of sample or specimen. The scrub practitioner must not discard any tissue or fluid until it has been ascertained that it is not required as a specimen to be sent for analysis.
The scrub practitioner must clearly relay this information to the circulating practitioner, who will assist in the collection process through accurate documentation.

The circulating practitioner must take care when selecting the appropriate specimen container. The container must be large enough to ensure that the specimen floats freely in the preservative medium, is completely covered in the preservative medium, with a securely fitting lid. Staff can contact the histology department for 25 litre containers if required.
The circulating practitioner must inspect the pot in which the specimen will be placed to ensure it is clean and empty.

When receiving a specimen from the sterile field, the circulating person must hold the container below the sterile field. This is in order to reduce the risk of contamination of the sterile field by the circulator or the specimen pot. Where the specimen is too large to be safely handed off the field, it must be placed in a sterile receiver or bowl and then handed to the circulating practitioner. (large sections of bowel, placenta etc.)

When receiving the specimen from the sterile field, the circulating practitioner must wear personal protective equipment as per the Policy for Infection Prevention and Control in Theatres. Precautions must be taken to prevent contamination to the outside of the container.
All specimen containers that contain a hazardous fixative MUST have an approved hazard label securely attached. Adhesive hazard labels are provided.

In working hours some histological specimens (frozen sections) will be sent to the labs ‘dry' in the appropriately sized container. Ensure Histology is informed that a ‘frozen section is to be sent to their department.
Out of hours the specimen will be put into a relevant sized container and covered with normal saline. The specimen can then be sent to the Histology department the next morning.
If specimens cannot be sent to a laboratory immediately, they should be stored in a specimen refrigerator at a temperature of 4 degrees this must be verified.
While a procedure is being carried out no other healthcare records should be taken into that clinical area/theatre.

A visual check must be undertaken by the scrub practitioner and surgeon to ensure that the specimen is inside the labelled container before it leaves the theatre. (This is not practice at Basildon hospital).
Documentation
Every specimen must be labelled on the actual specimen container and NOT ON THE LID (thereby preventing potential confusion over specimens if the lids are removed).
NB: At Basildon theatres labels are also placed on the lids.
After checking with the patient's healthcare records, the details on the label and investigation request form must include:
The patients full name
Their hospital number, NHS Number
Date of birth
Ward or department
Name of the responsible consultant .
Specimen present in the container with site if appropriate.

Details of the nature of the specimens. If there is more than one specimen recorded on one path lab form, both the specimen container and the path lab form must clearly indicate number of specimens and be clearly identified e.g. lettered a,b,c/numbered.
Date /time specimen was taken
Clinical information and investigations required to be completed by the clinician (on the request form only).
Signature of requesting clinician
The information on the investigation request form must correspond with the details on the specimen container and the patient's wrist band and notes.
It is the responsibility of the Clinician to complete and sign the request form and state what particular investigations are required.
A signed record to be kept of all specimens dispatched from the operating theatre in the histology log book
No specimen is to leave the Operating Department / or any department without a completed investigation request form.
It is recommended that it is documented in the peri-operative care plan adhering to the trust record keeping policy the specimens taken.
If pre-printed identification labels are used to label the specimen container they must be fully checked and the specimen type added to the label.

At Southend and Basildon theatres all patient labels are written out by hand checking against the consent form to reduce the chance of error. Details must not be transcribed from Sapphire/Nexus to avoid identification error.

At Southend theatres it is the responsibility of the medical staff to check that all details of the specimen label and form are correct before they leave the operating theatre which is incorporated into WHO sign out.
Specimens requiring special Consideration
Frozen sections It is essential that the Histology Department is notified that a frozen section is being carried out. This is the responsibility of the medical staff.

Whenever possible frozen sections should be pre booked, at least 24 hours before, with the Histology Department. The patient must be placed early on the theatre schedule. Only in exceptional circumstances and by liaison with a Consultant Histo- pathologist will a frozen section be accepted after 4.30pm.

It is the responsibility of the surgeon to notify the histology department of specimens requiring frozen section and to complete the investigation form prior to the start of the operation. The telephone number for the theatre in which the surgeon is working MUST be included on the investigation form to enable the results to be safely communicated.
Specimens for frozen section must be placed in a dry container.

Specimens for frozen section must be dispatched immediately, following the procedure for routine specimens. The specimen log book labelled ‘Frozen Sections' must accompany the specimen and returned to the theatre department following transportation.
The results of the frozen section should be given directly to the surgeon where possible. In other instances the results must only be given to a member of the
medical staff or a Registered Nurse. The person reporting the results should record the name of the person taking the results on behalf of the surgeon.
The results of the frozen section should be recorded in the patients operating notes by the surgeon.
Specimens for frozen section are placed in dry containers and MUST be dispatched immediately to the appropriate department.
Urgent specimens
Where a specimen is considered urgent by the clinician, this information must be clearly indicated on the investigation form.
The specimen and the investigation form should be dispatched to the appropriate department as soon as possible, following the same procedure for documentation and dispatch as with routine specimens.
Products of Conception
Procedure must be followed as per the Trusts Non-Viable Foetus Policy.

Account must be taken of any personal wishes expressed in respect of a foetus or foetal tissue. All foetal tissue samples must be sent to pathology with the histopathology request form completed by the doctor. If consent form (consent to dispose of tissue following surgical management of miscarriage/ERCP) is completed this is to accompany the tissue sample to pathology.
No Product of Conception sample will be accepted by the laboratory without a fully completed NVF consent form.

On occasions the consent form may not have been completed prior to surgery as the parents have not yet made a decision with regard to the chosen type of disposal. It is the gynaecology ward staff's responsibility to inform theatre staff this decision has not yet been made and to retrospectively send the form to pathology.
At Basildon theatres in some circumstances, products of conception can be sent straight to the mortuary
Karyotyping

If the products of conception are required to be sent to London for karyotyping this must be identified by the surgeon at the surgical brief. The yellow requesting slip must be stapled to the consent form which is always checked by the theatre staff and is a further precautionary measure.

10.6.1 When karyotyping is required the products of conception must NOT be placed in formalin. Half of the products are to be sent to London DRY OR IN NORMAL SALINE if there is a delay. The other half of products to go in formalin and sent to the laboratory with completed sensitive Disposal Form as usual procedure.
10.6.2 LONDON Specimen goes DRY in small white lid pot to the laboratory .

10.6.3 If out of hours, saline must be added to the specimen and it must be stored in a Theatre fridge. It must be sent at 8am next day to lab. The floor person must be informed and it must be documented in the theatre diary.
NB: Please refer to flow chart in appendix 1
Karyotyping at Basildon Hospital

10.7.1 Please check firstly if the patient wishes the specimen to go for karyotyping, if so this specimen MUST be kept dry and send to Gynae referral unit this is on D level, maternity block, please ensure that the staff on the unit are aware that the specimen is for karyotyping, but most importantly NO FORMALIN!!!! If the specimen is obtained out of hours ensure that the specimen is kept in the fridge until the unit is open.
10.7.2 The specimen for Karyotyping must NOT be split into 2 pots, if it is going for karyotyping the entire specimen must be sent.

10.7.3 If the consent for histopathology states that they want the sample to be sent to (histopathology and Karyotyping) please put the specimen into the fridge dry and await a senior member of staff to speak to the responsible Consultant.
10.7.4 If you are at all concerned or not sure just put the specimen in the fridge with the appropriate forms and it can be sorted the next day.

10.7.5 These 3 patients have had multiple miscarriages and needed these specimens to go for karyotyping to see if there is a genetic disorder which is causing them, please be very aware of what you are doing.

10.7.6 If the patient does not want any test done on the products of conception then the specimen should be sent to the mortuary with a white label for mortuary attention, the only information on the label should be the patients hospital number, the consent for need to go with the specimen.
Guide Wire Biopsies

Specimens must be x-rayed on the Faxitron machine by a member of the medical/theatre staff trained in the use of the Faxitron. At Southend theatres, the faxitron is stationed in the Day Stay Theatres. If a specimen is taken in Main Theatres it must be placed within a clear plastic bag, sealed and labelled with the patients details. It must then be placed inside a non-sea through container and transported to the day stay theatres by a member of staff who will stay with the labelled specimen, After it has been faxitroned the same member of staff must return the specimen to the main theatres where it be put into a specimen pot labelled and the appropriate fixative added to preserve it. At Broomfield the Faxitron machine is stationed in Day Stay Theatres . (very clear local protocol in place)

The circulating theatre practitioner must attach the patient identification label onto the clear bag and show it to the scrub practitioner. The scrub practitioner hands the specimen to the circulating practitioner to be placed flat inside the clear bag. This is

then taken to the Faxitron. On completion of the x-ray, the specimen is then taken back into the theatre and shown to the scrub practitioner. A label is prepared with the patients details and attached to the specimen pot. This is shown to the scrub practitioner and ensuring the pot is empty, the specimen is deposited and the lid attached.

In the event of being unable to use the Faxitron, the specimen must be placed within a clear plastic bag, sealed and labelled with the patients details. It must then be placed inside a non-see through bag and handed to a member of the x-ray staff, who will be responsible for the safe return of the specimen to theatre. It is the responsibility of the operating theatre staff to inform the x-ray department on extension 2232 that there is a guide wire biopsy for x-ray. The appropriate fixative must be added after the specimen has been x-rayed or Faxitroned to prevent deterioration of the specimen.

At Basildon theatres, the specimen is placed in a clear bag with the patient label and an orderly takes specimen to breast clinic. The orderly remains there and returns the specimen to the theatre where it is potted and labels attached.
If the breast unit is closed the xray department needs to be contacted and they will provide a member of staff to use the machine in the breast unit
Radio-active specimens
When dispatching radio-active specimens they must be labelled with a radio-active sticker.
11.6.1  At Broomfield hospital radio-active specimens are stored overnight. They are then transferred in a suitable container to the laboratory with a radio-active label.
Muscle Biopsies
In the event of taking a muscle biopsy in theatres, staff must liaise with histo- pathology department who will arrange transportation to Adenbrookes.

Samples should be placed in a sealed specimen tube; usually a 20ml universal tube will suffice. No fixative, saline or damp gauze should be used. This tube can then be placed into a specimen bag and transported to histo-pathology where it will be put into a small bucket of wet ice (not cardice) - this keeps the specimen cool for transportation without freezing it and then transported to Adenbrookes.
Microbiology
Swabs and fluids for microbiological examination must be transported individually, in a sealed plastic bag with the completed microbiology form.
24/7 hours
Urgent, dry, unfixed microbiology specimens may be placed in the pathology letter box at any time of the day or night. At the request of the surgeon, the on call
pathology technician will process urgent specimens 24/7.Advice must be sought from pathology when specimens are to be transferred to hospitals outside of the trust.
Further Considerations
When dispatching individual specimens within the working day, they should be transported either in the container or the bags provided by the Histology Department.

When dispatching specimens from Orsett Theatres, all procedures should be followed as outlined, with the addition of placing the specimen container in a sealed plastic bag prior to placing them in the provided transportation container. All documentation is completed as outlined.
Any non-adherence to this policy should be reported as per the incident reporting policy.
Procedure for logging and transportation of specimens

Where fixative is to be used for storage and transportation of the specimen, the fixative should be used only within the confines of the vapour cabinet located within each theatre department. Personal Protective Equipment should be used as per COSHH regulations for the handling of hazardous substances.
The container should be checked to ensure it is properly sealed.

The specimen should be entered in the appropriate Histology log book. The log book must contain the patient's name, hospital number and name of specimen. This must be witnessed by two members of staff, both of whom must sign and print their names in the appropriate space in the log book.
The specimens will be logged in to the operation register at Basildon theatres.
The specimen and the investigation form should then be placed together in the formalin cabinet at Basildon theatres.
Routine specimens are sent to the appropriate departments each morning, Monday through to Friday in a transportation container supplied by the Pathology Department.

A designated member of staff places the specimens in the transportation container, ensuring the patient's name and hospital number on the specimen is identical to the patient's name and hospital number on the investigation form. The member of staff placing the specimen in the transportation container then signs the log book.
When transporting any specimen to the appropriate lab, the specimen log book must always accompany the specimen and the investigation form.
On arrival in the appropriate department, the person receiving the specimen once again checks the following information is supplied:
The patient's full name.
The patient's hospital number / NHS number
The patient's date of birth
The patient's address (on the request form
The patient's ward
The name of the patient's consultant. The name must be written in full, initials are not acceptable.

Details of the nature of the specimen. Where more than one specimen is recorded on the same request form, both the specimen container and the request form must clearly indicate each individual specimen through the use of the alphabet a,b,c etc
Date/Time the specimen was taken where required.
Clinical information and investigations required to be completed by the clinician.
Signature of requesting clinician.
The receiving person must then sign the specimen log book in the appropriate column.

Where an error has been found after transportation, the specimen and the investigation form are returned to the theatre department and brought to the attention of the person in charge for rectification, then returned to the lab as soon as possible
IF THERE IS ANY DOUBT ABOUT SPECIMENS THE CONSULTANT IN CHARGE OF THE CASE MUST BE CONTACTED IMMEDIATELY FOR CLARIFICATION
Collection of specimens
Always follow standard precautions when handling specimens
Write details on the container immediately after taking the specimen, then place into the transport bag with the request form attached.
Wherever possible take the specimen prior to commencing antibiotics.
Where appropriate collect the specimen using sterile equipment and place in sterile containers. Ensure the outside of the container is free from contamination with body fluids.
When taking swabs from a dry area i.e. nasal screening, the tip should be moistened in sterile normal saline.
Do not over fill containers.
Ensure the lid is immediately secured to prevent spillage in transport.
Labelling
Specimens must be labelled correctly to prevent misdiagnosis and wastage.

All specimens and microbiology forms must be clearly labelled with the correct patient details which include, if there are not two identifiers e.g. full name and date of birth then the specimen will be discarded:
Patients full name
Patients address
Patients sex
Date of birth
NHS number
Relevant clinical details e.g. type of specimen, any clinical symptoms, description of a wound, medical conditions e.g. diabetes
Date and time of specimen collection
Signature (unless electronic)
Destination for report
Relevant medication history e.g. antibiotic history
High risk ‘biohazard' specimens
High risk micro-organisms in hazard group 3 include;
Tuberculosis (TB)
Human Immuno-Deficiency Virus (HIV)
Hepatitis B Virus (HBV)
Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)
Hepatitis E
E-Coli 0157
Salmonella Typhi/paratyphi (typhoid/Paratyphoid)
Rabies
Anthrax
Prions
Avian influenza e.g. SARS

This list is not exhaustive, the list contain those organisms most likely to be encountered. A full list of all group 3 pathogens can be found in the Health and Safety Executive document: The approved list of biological agents (2004). MRSA is not a high risk micro-organism.
Labelling of high risk specimens
Specimens identified as high risk and the request form/s must have a yellow biohazard/danger of infection sticker attached prior to placing in the transport bag.
Training requirements
Management of specimens is part of every staff induction and training with competencies

data.text: Monitoring and audit arrangements

20.2.1 The endoscopy unit is externally audited against the JAG Accreditation of Endoscopy Units including the adherence of the Global Rating Scores (GRS) Level B, to ensure best practice standards are being maintained at all times.
20.2.2 The effectiveness of this procedure for the taking of biopsies during procedures will be measured by:
A reduction in the number of reported clinical incidents concerning specimen collection.
A reduction in the number of near miss and adverse events reported.
An annual internal observation audit will be completed.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the T&A Divisional Governance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve MSE/local documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all relevant staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 2)
